title: Delivery & parcel scams (missed delivery / tracking links)
summary: Scammers send delivery-themed messages to trick you into clicking links, installing malware, or entering payment details.
how_it_works: You get a ‘missed delivery’ or ‘tracking’ message with a link.
The link may install malware or lead to a fake website.
Goal: steal info/money or infect your device.
warning_signs: Unexpected delivery message when you’re not expecting a parcel.
Asks you to install an app or enter details.
what_to_do: Don’t click—open the delivery company site/app directly and check.
Delete suspicious messages and report them.
If you installed something, run a security scan and change passwords.

quick_quiz.q: What’s the safest way to get to the real website?
choices: Click the link in the message
Type the website address yourself or use the official app
Reply and ask them for another link
quick_quiz.explain: Scam messages often include links to fake sites. Typing the address yourself (or using the official app) reduces that risk.

quick_quiz.q: A message says you must act 'within 24 hours' or you'll lose access. What should you do first?
choices: Stop and verify using official contact details you find yourself
Forward it to friends to ask
quick_quiz.explain: Urgency is a classic pressure tactic. Verify using trusted contact details.
